summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. It details an agreement between the prosecution and defense on proposed redactions to legal filings, specifically concerning Exhibit 11 and the Government's omnibus memorandum of law. The letter highlights disputes over redacting information already public in the indictment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom this letter is addressed.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this letter to the court.

connections.description: Strauss, as U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against defendant Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Maxwell.

events.title: Court Order on Redactions
events.description: The Court issued an order regarding proposed redactions to case filings.

events.title: Defense Submission of Cover Letter
events.description: The defendant's legal team submitted a cover letter with proposed redactions.

keyFacts: The prosecution and defense reached an agreement on redactions for Exhibit 11 and a defense cover letter.

The defense reversed its position, requesting that originally proposed redactions on pages 118-119 of the Government's brief remain in place, as they reference a sealed exhibit from a related civil case (v. Maxwell, 15 Civ. 7433 (LAP)).
The Government notes that some defense-proposed redactions would conceal language already publicly available in the filed Indictment, particularly in Count Six.
The defense requested an additional, last-minute redaction on page 134, which the Government agreed to include pending court approval, despite noting it also covers public information.
